title: Solomon, Syfrett & Durrett
content: I'm not so sure I agree with Baskerville. The 'e' has a slightly slanted bar, and the 'f' has a shallower 'crook' than any Baskerville I am seeing. The ampersand could have come from a collection of ampersands like [these two fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518124335/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/ampersands/) from Castle Type.
author: bowfinpw

comments.content: I believe this is Times Roman. It appears to be cut or cast letters applied to a wall and some of them (like the e) are a bit crooked. The baseline is also crooked and the spacing is a bit loose and uneven.

Also, I think it has been stretched a little horizontally.   
   
I should note that I'm having trouble finding a precise match with any of the common digital versions of Times. But I don't think that means it's not Times. There are so many versions of this face--both authorized and unauthorized. It might also be pre-digital.   
   
In any case, I am convinced that it is some version of Times.

As for the ampersand, it's a little like the one in [Cooper Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518124335/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/cooper-black/cooper-black/testdrive.html?s=%26&p=72), too. My gut feeling is that it was custom designed.
